steps.question: Welcome Cassandra! Are you ready to begin your story?
You've caught the eye of a god- Phoebus Apollo. You serve as a priestess in his temple. He approaches you and makes his intentions clear.

How could you turn down such a radiant, charming god? You and Apollo kindle a romance. After a little while, he offers you a gift as a token of his affection. The gift is fitting for a god of prophecy - he wants to make you a prophetess.

You know what happens to women who get entangled in gods' business, and you don't want any part in it. Besides, he's not your type. You tell him this, but he isn't dissuaded. He offers you a gift in return for your affection - the gift of prophecy.

choices.choice: Feign interest until you can get the gift

steps.question: You accept the gift, eager to become a prophetess of Apollo. Over time, your gift for prophecy becomes known, and Trojan men and women come to you for some insight into their futures. Apollo continues to visit you at night when it pleases him, but you begin to have a feeling you're not his only lover. You think you catch glimpses of him sometimes, slipping into the forest with a nymph or a fisherman's daughter.

How dare you turn down a gift from the great Apollo? You want to explain, but he's too furious to listen. Knowing he intends to punish you for your ingratitude, you try to flee. But before you can take a step, you're overcome by drowsiness, and the sight of the temple fades from your vision as you fall into an enchanted sleep.

You awake on the hard floor of the temple, with a sharp pain in your left ear. You turn your head and are met with the sight of a snake staring into your eyes. You scream and scramble away, but the snake is already slithering out of sight, past the statue of Apollo. Shaken, you scan the room for signs of the god himself, but you're alone. You touch your ear. What has he done? Has he placed a curse on you? You don't feel cursed. You resolve to go to a loved one for comfort and council.

You're enticed by the offer of seeing into the future. You tell Apollo that you had been afraid that his love wasn't true, but now that he offers such a gift you can see how strongly he cares for you. You clasp his hand and beg forgiveness. Will he still have you? Of course he will, he assures you.  You exchange promises: him that you will have the gift of prophecy until your death, and you that you will be his. You then return home, promising to return that night. You don't return. Instead, you practice your new gift of prophecy.

choices.choice: Look into the future of Troy

steps.question: Ever since Helen came to Troy with your brother Paris, she's been like a sister to you. You're sure that you'll feel better after talking to her. You find her weaving in the palace, and greet her. But before you can say anything, Helen begins to transform in front of you. Visions of war swirl around her. You can smell the stench of death and hear men's cries: "Helen! Hell to men! Hell to Troy!" Helen looks down at you with fire in her eyes. Is she some kind of witch come to destroy your people, starting with you? She takes a step forward.

You seek out your father Priam, king of Troy. On your way to the palace, you see your brother, Paris. He greets you, but you feel uneasy. Then, you're struck by a realization: Paris and Helen will bring destruction to Troy. Your own brother and his wife! The knowledge comes from somewhere deep within yourself, and you have no doubt that it is true.

You tell Apollo you don't wish to see him anymore. He can go be with one of his other women, if he likes them enough to sneak around with them. He tries to charm you, but you firmly reject his advances, and his charm turns to anger. You dare to defy a god? He curses you. From now on, no one will believe your prophecies again.

You don't say anything about the other women. You don't much care what Apollo does -- at this point he is just an amusement to you, as you are to him. You have no wish to marry him or have his children. And so the affair continues, and the prophecies continue. One day a vision comes to you that is unlike the rest. It comes to you like a knife and leaves you feeling nauseous: the imminent destruction of Troy. When you tell Apollo about your vision, he tells you not to share your prophecy with anyone.

You fall on Helen in a rage, wrestling with her and throwing her to the floor. Her screams bring Paris running, and he pulls you off her. When the vision subsides, you see Helen as she is, not a witch or a destroyer, but just Helen. They ask you if you've gone mad. Thinking more clearly now, you realize you've received Apollo's gift after all: prophecy.

choices.choice: Tell Paris and Helen about your vision

steps.question:
You flee the room, frantic to get away from Helen. When you can think clearly again, you think this must be a punishment from Apollo. He wants to terrify you with violent visions; it means nothing.

You bear it as well as you can, until one day the news arrives: Greece has declared war on Troy. And the cause? Helen. You realize Apollo has given you the gift of prophecy after all. But why?

After the war begins, your premonitions come to you more and more often. Sometimes it's a vision, and other times a bone-deep conviction that creeps up on you unexpectedly. The common thread is that they are never pleasant, and they always come true. You try to warn your father, but he never listens.

You try to look into the future, but your new gift is not easily harnessed. The prophecies come to you unprompted. Sometimes it's a vision, and other times a bone-deep conviction that creeps up on you unexpectedly. You can't help but prophecy. You speak out in the temple, in the streets, in your own home. And people listen. Eventually, Apollo grows tired of your excuses and evasion. He confronts you about your promise to him.

You urge Paris to take Helen back to Greece. You warn him that he will bring death and destruction upon Troy if he doesn't listen. But Paris doesn't like being told what to do. Since when do you know anything? He scoffs and continues on his way.

You leave Paris and seek out your father, King Priam. You warn him that Helen must return to Greece or Troy will be destroyed. He thinks you're out of line to make such bold unfounded claims, so you tell him of Apollo and the snake. Surely your prophecy is a gift from the god! But this only upsets Priam further. Apollo wouldn't bless someone who rejected and disobeyed him; it is more likely that the snake brought you a curse. You must not be trusted.

It's hard to keep your knowledge of the future to yourself, but you know that it's always best to have the gods on your side. But Apollo wants war, and sure enough, war comes. For 10 long years, you watch your brothers and fellow Trojans fight and die, and you grow gradually more angry at the god, as he continues to lose interest in you. Sensing your anger and pain, Apollo wants to make sure you aren't a threat to his plans, so he curses you. From now on, no one will believe your prophecies again. It isn't fair, you did everything he asked of you!

You can't just stand by and wait for Troy to burn. You go to anyone you can get to listen to you - family members, citizens, priests - and the prophecies pour out of you, burning your throat. But Apollo is angry - he wants war and he doesn't appreciate insolent mortals. He places a curse on you: from now on, no one will believe your prophecies again.

Your prophecies get worse. You foresee 10 years of bloody war with Greece, and are forced to watch it all come true. You go to anyone you can get to listen to you - family members, citizens, priests - and the prophecies pour out of you, burning your throat. All of your warnings go unheeded, no matter how passionately you convey them.

You don't know why Apollo has gifted you with prophecy after you scorned him, but you have to take advantage of it. You apologize to Helen, and tell the couple about your vision, advising that she return to Greece. Paris tells you to leave his home, and never lay hands on his wife again. Wherever you go, the reception is the same: no one believes you. People groan when you come near them: here comes crazy doomsday Cassandra.

You don't know why Apollo has gifted you with prophecy after you scorned him, but you have to take advantage of it. You apologize to Helen, and pull your brother aside. You tell him about your vision, urging him to return Helen to Greece. Paris tells you to leave his home, and never lay hands on his wife again. Wherever you go, the reception is the same: no one believes you. People groan when you come near them: here comes crazy doomsday Cassandra.

You call on Apollo, make sacrifices and begging him for help. You want him to explain what he's done to you - the gift that became a curse. But it seems Apollo isn't done punishing you, or else he simply thinks you aren't worth his time. You turn to the public, but your prophecies continue to be ignored. For 10 years, you're forced to watch your fellow Trojans fight and die in the war.
You turn to the public, but your prophecies continue to be ignored. For 10 years, you're forced to watch your fellow Trojans fight and die in the war.

At last, it seems like Troy has prevailed: the Greeks retreat, leaving behind a wooden horse as a peace offering dedicated to the goddess Athena. You are the only one who sees the horse for what it is: a Greek trap that will bring destruction to your city.

choices.choice: Try to get a trustworthy priest on your side

steps.question: You tell Apollo the truth: that you don't want to be with him. He tries to charm you, but you firmly reject his advances, and his charm turns to anger. You dare to defy a god? He curses you. From now on, no one will believe your prophecies again.

You change your mind, and decide to give Apollo a chance. He has been quite generous to you after all, and you don't want to break your promise. The two of you kindle a romance.  He visits you at night when it pleases him, but you begin to have a feeling you're not his only lover. You think you catch glimpses of him sometimes, slipping into the forest with a nymph or a fisherman's daughter.
You beg the military commanders not to trust the Greeks. The horse is a trap! It will bring destruction on Troy! No one believes you, and you're unable to stop them.

Laocoon is an esteemed elder priest you have known since childhood. Knowing he won't believe your prophecies, you question him instead: Can we really trust the Greeks? Do you suppose the horse is hollow inside, or solid wood? The priest becomes suspicious of the horse, and warns everyone not to bring it in the city. But as soon as the words have left his mouth, a sea monster rises from the ocean and kills him. The Trojans interpret this as divine judgement against him for dishonoring the offering to Athena.

choices.choice: Try to stop them from bringing in the gift

steps.question: The horse is brought inside the city. That night, Greek soldiers come out of the wooden horse and open the gates for the rest of the army to come flooding in. The streets of Troy are killed with chaos and screaming as the enemy sacks the city.

You find your parents in the heart of the palace. But even there, you are not safe; the palace is breached by the enemy. One of your brothers, Polites, bursts into the room, pursued by the Greek soldier Neoptolemus. He is struck down right in front of your horrified father. You and Priam rush toward the killer, but the king is an old man and you are not a warrior. There is only one way for this to end.

You seek sanctuary in the temple of Athena, praying for her to protect you. A Greek soldier, Ajax the lesser, drags you from her altar. Athena will later send storms to kill him and his fellow soldiers for what he does, but it doesn't make up for it. Nothing could.

You are taken back to Greece as a slave to the Greek commander and king Agamemnon. You learn of the deaths of your parents, brothers, and countless other people dear to you. When you arrive at the palace, you foresee your own death alongside Agamemnon at the hands of his wife, Clytemnestra.

Your family and home have been destroyed, so where would you run? You've learned that you can't escape fate. All you know how to do is prophesy, so you prophesy. You curse Apollo and murderous Clytemnestra, and the bloody house of Atreus. There is no one to hear except some nearby old men. You know they won't believe you, but it doesn't matter. Even if they did, why would they care about your life? You are a stranger and slave here. You allow yourself to be led into the palace
You know that if you enter the palace, you'll be walking into your own death. Desperately, you try to make a break for the woods, but are quickly caught and dragged into the palace.

You enter the palace. There is nothing to be done at that point; you are defenseless and easily struck down. It is done by the queen, Clytemnestra, as you foresaw. It isn't your fault. It was always going to end this way.
